ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about how to think critically and logically in all sorts of situations.

The course covers the fundamentals of game theory. This includes normal form matrix games, pure and mixed Nash equilibriums, simultaneous and sequential games, backwards induction, and various models of competition.
Game Theory helped me to understand how and why we make the choices we do, and presents systems to visualize and process tough puzzles of choice.
Game theory principles and methods. Backwards induction.
How to identify games, finding simplicity in complexity, how to formalize and communicate your knowledge, limited math, how various global questions and issues can be solved as games.
I gained a broad understanding of how to solve many different types of games, as well as some of the social implications for the theories we learned.
I learned how to navigate situations with many options and weigh payoffs.
prisoner's dilemmas, strategy domination, backward induction, ultimatums, repeated games, subgame perfect equilibria, ...

Countless different games and strategies. How to solve Nash Equilibria of complicated games including e.g. simultaneous and sequential move games. This course taught a lot about how the real world works as well. Investment strategies, when cooperation can be sustained and so on.
backward induction, strategic thinking, solving for equilibria of pure and mixed strategies
Strategic thinking; logic; problem-solving. This class teaches you HOW to think more explicitly than most other college classes---super valuable, and I think will stay with me for a long time.
I learned how to think about problems logically, which is extremely undervalued.
Game theory
Critical thinking skills, different game theories.
I learned how to think effectively and more strategically in my everyday decisions.

I learned how to approach games with a more quantitative (and honestly qualitative too) strategy, and feel more confident in my ability to navigate topics in economics. A great mental exercise even if you're not an economics or social science major.

I learned a lot from this course. I learned the basics of game theory and how it applies to economics and to other issues in my day-to-day life. The concept of backwards induction has really changed how I view the world
This course completely reframes your thinking about the world. You learn frameworks of analyzing complex situations
I learned the skill of game evaluation along with backwards induction.

This course taught me many concepts involving the thoughts of others. It is very interesting because it emphasizes thinking far more steps ahead of the other person than usually accustomed to. This is applicable not only to daily life, but also in professional environments.
Introduction to game theory and some logical thinking skills

Game theory was an amazing course and taught me how to both use my accumulated knowledge that was taught and trust my problem solving capabilities. I learned how to stay calm and approach a problem in a strategic way when it was unfamiliar. I also learned a lot of useful subjects that are applied to real life.

I learned the basics of Game Theory. Dominant strategies, Nash equilibrium, mixed strategies, sequential games, imperfect information, repeated games, signaling, and a bunch of other stuff. I think the problem sets helped me practice class concepts well. I learned that models are valuable even if they aren't perfect representations of reality.
You learn how to think critically and put yourself in abstract situations. The course also teaches you to be resilient. A lot of problems may seem daunting at first, but then fall into pieces.
Learned the basics of game theory and how to analyze different real world applications with a game theory mindset.
Basic game theory skills: Nash equilibrium, backwards induction, how to think logically like the economist's ideal.
none
One of the best classes I have taught at yale. warning: it is not an easy class but also teaches you how to think. highly recommend.
I learned to look at life in a more strategic way. I also learned how to anticipate other's decisions and preform backward induction.
Fundamental stuff of game theory.
This course really pushes you to analyze everyday situations in a more nuanced way. Critical thinking and problem-solving skills.

This is a spectacular introductory course that is ostensibly about how to solve simultaneous and sequential games under perfect and asymmetric information, but is really just about how to think, problem solve, and be smarter.
basic game theory principles
Backward Induction!
Basic techniques for analysis of game-like scenarios, learned interesting application to real-life situations

How to use game theory decision-making models in everyday real world applications - I consistently find myself drawing payoff matrices and thinking about my life situations under a game theory lens - it's truly made an impact on how I view the world.
I thought this course gave me a better understanding of strategic interactions and the way people make decisions. I found it fascinating.
Game theory basics.
I learned all about game theory. This included tress, matrices, and application to real life.
I learned how to analyze different games through systematic analysis.
New lens of game theory (especially incentives and problem solving skills) through which to look at the world.
Learned the ins and outs of game theory and its applications in really cool areas.

This course was such an interesting one. We learned how individuals think, how businesses think, how society thinks. It was very informative, and I feel like I learned a lot about human behavior without it being a psychology class. Not only do I feel more qualified to analyze economic and political choices in the form of Game Theory, but I also found myself in casual conversations and situations analyzing like it was a game we learned in class.
Learned a lot about the fundamentals of game theory
I learned a lot about economics and game theory and logical thinking and problem solving.
how to think critically to solve different games
None. How to memorise names of games I suppose.
I learnt how to think an approach analyzing games in the first place. I also learnt the intricacies of decision making and the complexities of understanding what is known to who in a game.
How to make decisions while playing with rational actors. I have been able to apply the principles we learned in the class about first mover advantage/second mover advantage to my own life even.
Basic game theory knowledge
All about game theory
I learned about different games and how to solve for equilibria, with many hands-on applications to real-life problems and games.
I learned lots of different game theory concepts and learned to apply them to everyday scenarios. For instance, we learned about duels, wars of attrition, bargaining, etc.
I learned how to reason through the decision-making process. Particularly, I learned about the utility of solving problems using backwards induction.
On an overly simplified level, the societal implications of game theory.
logic

This course is so interesting and fun. I really loved learning from Ben (such an engaging and funny professor) and I learned so much about game theory, rational thinking, and real-world applications. This course definitely challenged me to think about games in new ways.
This course provided valuable practice for my strategic intuition and, although the games we played were often assumption-heavy, many of the lessons we learned were quite meaningful.
A broad overview of how to solve various problems in game theory using methods such as matrices and trees as well as developing a framework/new way of looking at the world
A basic understanding of game theory

Thinking about tons of different types of situations in a methodical way. Whether it is a war of attrition, a sequential decision game of signing contracts, or figuring out what the effects are of raising a toll fee, I have been introduced to ways to approach these problems through trees, matrices, etc.
Game theory is super interesting. Highly recommend. Learned a lot.
knowledge of how to solve complex games, intuition for applications across a wide variety of fields and situations

In this class, I gained insight into evaluating strategic situations such as those between firms or warring armies. The concepts such as repetition as it relates to coordination and "duel" were very interesting though challenging. The skills that I gained from this class are intangible and thus hard to explain, and we often examined situations with a lot of simplifying assumptions. That being said, the professor is wonderful and the class is genuinely fun to attend.

Foundational game theory: simultaneous and sequential games, Nash equilibria, evolutionary stability, subgame perfect equilibria, backward induction, etc. Other than conceptual knowledge, the course also helped students practice approaching difficult problems.

Use backwards induction! incentive design is important - changing the rules of the game or the payoffs of the game can change behavior. There are cases when communication is helpful (coordination problem) and there are cases when communication does nothing (prisoner's dilemma). Your payoffs determine the probabilities of the other players strategy in a mixed equilibrium.
I learned. lot about problem-solving throughout this course. Everything was based on logic, so I feel like I developed my way of thinking through this course.
I learned more about game theory and how people or firms think.
I gained the ability to analyze situations based on the thoughts and actions of others.

The best things you learn in this course are the concepts of backward induction and putting yourself in others' shoes. This course elevates your critical thinking approach and your intuition to games and illustrates how even the most seemingly mundane assumptions in models can cause drastic deviations in equilibrium outcomes. I would say the most valuable thing this course offers is intuition into games, which can and will translate to real-life situations.
Foundations of game theory and logic

Many of the takeaways of the class like backwards induction, how an apparent strength can actually end up being a weakness, how signaling works, seeing things as equilibria in politics and economic competition, are extremely important to strategic thinking and widely applicable to many fields and positions in the future. The course changed my thinking for the better.

GT totally teaches you a new way of behavioral thinking. It taught me to be analytic, to think in economics, as well as to use different tools of induction and deduction to think about how people act.
I learned how to break down game set-ups at a conceptual level and how these concepts apply across a range of real-world examples and disciplines.

I learned the basics of game theory including dominate strategies, backwards induction, evolutionary stability, hold up problems, and more. This course helped my critical thinking skills as I practiced thinking outside the box to solve the games in class.
I am now equipped to rule the world.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Well structured and taught

This course has clearly been finely tuned over the many years that Professor Polak has taught it. I don't have any criticisms. Lecture was fun, the exams were fair, and the problem sets were challenging yet doable.

The structure of the course is fantastic. It offers a lot of flexibility as all of the material is posted online, including lectures. The psets are also well rooted in the material from the course and really helps in understanding the content. There are honestly no major weaknesses with this course, probably one of the best and most accessible courses in the Econ department.
I wish that one PSET (out of 10) could be dropped. Otherwise, very interesting!

Strengths - amazing lectures and professor, abundant office hours with TAs and peer tutors, short p-sets, very engaging and interesting content, fair exams, and playing games in class keep you engaged. 
Weaknesses - p-sets are answered/solved fully before the due date if you go to office hours causing you to not even try on your own by the end of the semester.

The biggest strength is Prof. Polak - he is legendary for this course, and for good reason. Lectures were engaging and fun to attend, and his sense of humor made them even better. The exams were very fair, and the problem sets - while difficult - were helpful in reinforcing my understanding. I'd say the biggest weakness of the course was that solutions to problem sets were not posted - it made studying for exams much harder and felt unnecessarily annoying. It also made it hard to understand why points were taken off on problem sets.

This course was well organized and really designed for people to succeed. The professor even gave extra office hours to help explain PSET questions. It is a really tough course though so it needed that extra effort I think

strengths - prof polak is an experienced lecturer and very personable so lectures are always entertaining. the in-class games are great. psets are reasonable, exams are HARD but fair. but HARD. study study. do all the practice questions twice
weaknesses - none really. the tfs and prof were very accommodating and willing to help.

Strengths: Amazing professor. A lot of Office Hours provided. Absolutely GREAT Peer tutor Beichen Zhang!
Weaknesses: Often hard to keep up with lecture topics and different games because covering so much content.
very engaging games played in class that made lectures very fun to attend, interesting and funny lectures. exams can definitely be tough but workload is manageable

Strenthgs: very engaging lectures, stimulating p-sets with helpful office hours, and a wide variety of interesting and relevant material covered. Weaknesses: not a lot of opportunities for individual help with understanding, feedback on assignments was not helpful

Strengths: Ben Polak! He's the reason this class is so popular. Every lecture is engaging, and he's clearly very thoughtful and intentional about pedagogy. The psets were also great---they never felt like busywork, and were a nice opportunity to run in logical circles with friends every Wednesday night.

Weaknesses: I'm not sure what the pedagogical reason was for only giving pset answers verbally in section (not posted online, even after the due date). Sometimes we didn't get through the whole pset, and sometimes I wasn't sure I wrote the answer correctly. It would have been nice to have a way to check when studying for exams.
I really enjoyed everything about the course.
Great lectures, many outlets to help students learn

Strengths: Ben Polak has taught this class for many years, he knows how how to teach the material.
Weaknesses: It's hard to pinpoint, but the class felt pretty disjointed. Psets are also really difficult and not actually graded so hard to even get feedback on your work. Also no pset drops/late days are allowed which makes it a bit tough sometimes.
Very interesting content
I think that for the homework, we should've gotten more feedback. It felt like completion most of the time which wasn't very constructive for my learning.

Class was engaging, professor was one of the best I've had at Yale, and the problems were genuinely interesting (or made interesting) to learn about

Section was not helpful for me personally; they only went through the problem set answers instead of reviewing topics from the previous week. Would have preferred the latter

Strengths: I think that this course was super engaging. The topics that we covered were all really interesting. I loved going to class every day
Weaknesses: I object a little to how the midterm was structured. It was a few true/false and one really long question. I think that this unfairly punishes students who happen to not "see" how to do the long question. I think it makes more sense to do two medium-sized questions instead of one really long question
Very engaging, interesting problem sets, lectures are actually fun and interesting (unlike many other econ courses)
This course is the most engaging lecture I've ever taken.

At times the concepts were hard to adapt to and Professor Polak might move through it too fast but beyond that, he is so incredibly funny and charismatic, and it certainly kept the attention of the class. I do wish the problem set solutions were posted or at the very least, more feedback could be given on Gradescope. I do appreciate how interactive the class was with polls and physical examples.

Strengths - Polak is a very engaging lecturer and makes the material very interesting and applicable.
Weaknesses - Psets were overly challenging, games got repetitive at the end of the semester.
I don't think there are many weaknesses to this course. It was extremely engaging and informative. Maybe the one thing is to have pset solutions posted after students hand them in.

Professor Polak is an incredible lecturer. He made even this 300+ student course engaging. The games he chose are relevant to real life, and I enjoyed his random mentions of historical facts and TV shows. I thought the course overall was really well organized.
Weakness: (small) some of the office hours ended up becoming just problem set review instead of a chance to get hints to try solving the problems ourselves.
the lectures and professor are awesome

Strength: Ben Polak is a FANTASTIC lecturer. His humor and wit make the class much more lively than the other economics lecture I've taken. I also enjoy studying for the finals a lot. I honestly learned a lot just by getting a group of friends and then working through past exams with them.

Weaknesses: Can't really think of any. This is one of the canonical classes at Yale for a reason.

Strengths: Professor Polak is an engaging lecturer who made classes enjoyable and engaging. The problem sets and exams were all reasonable. Overall, this was my favorite class this semester!

Weaknesses: I would strongly prefer if the sections functioned as addendums to the lectures rather than just going through the problem sets. Also, we would sometimes not finish the problem sets in section, and since the solutions were never released, we would just not know, which was frustrating and made exam preparation more difficult. Please just release the solutions!!!

Lectures are fantastic. Professor Polak is really engaging, and the material is conveyed very well. There is a lot of support for the material and psets. I felt like I got all the material I needed from class and never really needed much additional guidance.

very hard material
good examples in class

teaches you how to think. 
sometimes psets are challenging and don't reflect well midterms or final exam content.
The professor is incredible!!!

Strength: Prof. Polak is a great lecturer, very engaging and clear.
Weakness: the pace is a bit slow for me, but that's a personal feeling.

This class is very engaging and extremely interesting. Even though you might not use the exact formulas you learn in real life, you still feel that you will use the overall skills and logic taught by the class in everyday life.

The lectures were truly some of the most spectacular lectures that I've ever seen. I would've appreciated more practice problems to apply the lecture matieral, specifically in preparation for the exams, which were (reasonable, but) challenging.
lecture slides need to be posted before class
Interesting material, felt a little drawn out at times especially with all of the Nash Equilibria stuff

I thoroughly enjoyed the logic puzzles without an overabundance of math, but felt that some more math could have been useful/even enlightening. The psets were well-suited to gauge our understanding of course concepts. The lecture slides were sometimes difficult to understand following lecture, but the recordings aided in recall.

I thought the lectures were engaging and the exams felt fair, but I wish office hours were more evenly distributed throughout the week. They were stacked right before PSET due dates, which makes sense in theory but in practice makes it hard to finish a PSET far in advance of the due date if you have any questions about it. This can be especially problematic in busy weeks when you want to clear out your PSET work load over the weekend.

Strengths: Lectures and exams
Weaknesses: The last lecture was NOT sufficient preparation for the final question on the exam. That felt unfair.
Good professor, good class, fair tests, fair Psets. Solid econ elective and I learned a lot.
Strengths - incredible lectures and guidance on problems sets

The class is well-taught, but it was better taught on open yale courses. The discussion sections were really unhelpful, and I feel like they would be more useful if they were spent explaining the lecture material and going over other practice questions (instead of just reviewing the pset). It seemed like no one was very engaged in the course.
Really well organized and lots of resources in terms of practice material and office hours available.
A strength was the quality of the lectures and the experience of the course. A weakness was the flipped classroom problems.
The course attempts to cover too many games. I wish they would focus on fewer and explain them further.
Ben Polak is one of my favorite lecturers at Yale. Content is quite approachable, and he does an excellent job teaching it.
Psets help form understanding, exams apply concepts in novel ways, lectures funny and informative!
No complaints- interesting content, amazing lectures, and strong student support.

This course is very engaging because of Professor Ben Polak. On its own, the course material is a little dry. But, his explanations and enthusiasm in lecture really make you want to attend and learn. I think improvements could come in section. I understand we need to know how to do the homework problems. However, when we are given the solution (and work) for one problem a week already in the flipped classroom, I had less of an incentive to attend section. I felt confident about my other homework problems, so I did not go to section as much as I should have. If section were designed as mandatory with other example problems and further explanation of lecture concepts, I think i would have felt more prepared to solve out games on my own. I followed the content in lecture clearly, but often felt I could not do the work on my own. This is where I think a redesign of section would help.
Benjamin Polak is best professor I've had. Lots of learning through games and examples made the process more engaging and fun
Could have separate discussion section questions
The course was very well organized and well taught.

Strength: lots of office hours and peer tutor hours to help with PSETs
Weaknesses: the class was much harder than expected (after reading all the past reviews on the class, i disagree with what many people said... the class is very challenging and takes A LOT of time and effort), and the PSETS were quite challenging. The lectures went by really fast, and it was difficult to understand the concepts.

Would be great if a quarter of the exam was not based on memorising the names (names by the instructor, not actually conventional games) and outcomes of such games. Given that the grades are curved, this entails a lot of time spent on dry memorisation. Not the most engaging activity.

I believe the course is very good and clearly explaining what could be very difficult ideas to initially grasp. It was very different to anything I did before and I liked how it started off slowly. It was sometimes hard to grasp concepts in class but the recordings were a lifesaver and I think every class should have them.

Strengths: Professor Polak is a highly engaging professor. The support system of TFs and peer tutors was phenomenal.

Weaknesses: tests count for a significant portion of the grade, and only having two questions on the midterm can be very harmful to students' grades.
Problem solving and social structure analysis
Great lectures

This is such a fun lecture class. Professor Polak is great and has so much experience with the course. It's well-organized and the TFs are super helpful. There's a lot of support for problem sets and office hours, which is also great. Sometimes Professor Polak can go through content quite fast, but all lectures are recorded and he'll often go back and explain something if a lecture was rushed at the end.

This course is very interesting and Professor Polak is extremely engaging as well. The lectures are well-structured and clearly-presented. The only weakness is that I wish that discussion sections provided us with new practice material instead of only going over the previous week's P-Set. I also wish that we received more feedback on P-Sets and exams to better understand what we did wrong (i.e. by receiving an answer key).
For a lecture class, the course is very engaging, which helped me retain the concepts we discussed in lecture.
The lectures in isolation are interesting, engaging, and societally-relevant, but they feel very far removed from the problem sets and exams.
econ curve is the worst

Strengths: Professor Polak was a kind and fun instructor that made lectures interactive and engaging, and the TFs are super helpful and understanding. I found the topics we learned to be very interesting, and I enjoyed the critical thinking/problem-solving aspect of the course. Weaknesses: The course is fast-paced, so missing a lecture or two can make it hard to catch up. Also, since almost everyone did very well on the PSETs, it put more weight on the midterm and final, which made studying for these exams a little stressful (especially considering the econ departmental curve.

Biggest strength of the course: Ben Polak. I LOVE THIS MAN he's so wonderful and makes every class entertaining.
Possible improvements: make more office hours and peer tutoring available later in the week, for some reason, there were basically only Monday-Wednesday which was sometimes hard to fit into my schedule.
I found the lectures very engaging and the problem set questions thought-provoking. Sections were often very similar in structure to office hours.

Strengths: overview of many interesting games, the incorporation of real-world examples, engaging lectures

Weaknesses: no problem-set solutions posted, which is challenging come time for studying for exams

The course was pretty well organized, although I found it frustrating and ridiculous that PSet solutions were not posted. I think the point of this was to force office hours attendance and i thought it was pointless.

Strengths: REALLY caters to student learning, Professor Polak is also the BEST and does so much to try and make sure students' needs are met; tons of different section times, and Professor Polak does a "reverse classroom" where he does a problem from the pset over Zoom with the students
Weaknesses: just a super massive class, so it might be difficult to receive individualized attention to where you are misunderstanding things; for many people maybe this was okay, but I felt that the lectures were a little too quick for me
The lectures are excellent.

strengths: very engaging and fun professor and very helpful and available TF team, course is very well-structured and professor seems to have perfected it after 15+ years of teaching
weaknesses: very large class size and recorded lectures make it very easy to not engage fully with class, but this is up to students personally

The class moves very fast and covers a lot of information. On the positive side, the material is very interesting, the class is very fun (with a lot of student involvement) and the professor is wonderful. He is very funny and makes sure to keep the students engaged. Additionally, Professor Polak holds a "flipped classroom" covering the hardest question on the pset, rewarding students for effort. I do wish that he would post the solutions to the problem sets for exam review instead of just going over it in section, but that is relatively minor.

This course is quite good. The choice of games was interesting, as are the problem sets. Prof. Polak is a slam-dunk of a professor. However, I strongly disliked the pop quizzes that Prof. Polak experimented with this semester. I prefer to do my classes asynchronously, but these forced me to come in person, only to get nothing out of them (entirely due to my own inability to focusnot Prof. Polak, who is an OUTSTANDING lecturer). In the end, I still spent the same amount of time reviewing the slides that I'd have otherwise spent had I skipped the lectures, so attending them was a redundant time-waster for me. I got an A without meaningfully watching the lectures, suggesting that in-person attendance probably isn't necessary, but I STRONGLY encourage those with better attention spans than mine to get as much out of the lectures as they can. Although my inattention is my fault and mine alone, I would've perhaps had an easier time if Prof. Polak had spoken faster (but maybe that's just me). I didn't think that the concepts in this class were complicated enough to justify how slowly he moved.

A few other areas for improvement: the exams could've been harder to more meaningfully discriminate between students; I don't like how Prof. Polak structures his exam questions (2a, 2b, 2c, etc., but often with multiple subquestions in each lettered sub-question, instead of just going 2ai, 2aii, 2aiii, etc.); the reasoning when grades were deducted from psets wasn't always clear; etc.

ALTHOUGH I'VE DEDICATED MUCH MORE SPACE TO THIS COURSE'S WEAKNESSES, ITS STRENGTHS TRIUMPH AND I HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT.

I felt like the course was a very strong course overall, but the primary strength I'd like to highlight is that the course felt very well-organized in a way that facilitated student learning. While problem sets were always a step up in difficulty compared to lecture examples, I felt like they prepared us well for the exams, and testable content on exams was always very clear. One policy I think could be changed is that solutions to problem sets were not released. I think the intention was that the professor wanted students to attend section to discuss solutions with a TA, but I feel like it would have been helpful to have solutions available, especially when going back to review problem sets before exams.
I overall enjoyed the course and the course content, but found a handful of the teaching fellows to be unhelpful.

The strengths of the course was the abundance of office hours and help that was offered to us students. In addition to this, I appreciated how organized everything was within the class. Everything followed the syllabus smoothly. One area that I found difficult was the problem sets. I remember the first week, my friend and I went to five hours worth of office hours because we needed help with a singular question and not a single office hours made it throughout the entire question. In addition to this, each TF solved the problem with a different method, so we struggled to understand how to solve the question.

Strengths: recorded lectures 
Weaknesses: Final Exam was hard

Strengths: extremely engaging and interesting

Weaknesses: none to report--dropping a pset perhaps would have been beneficial though

Lectures are recorded which is always a plus. P-sets are not the plug-and-chug type and most likely will require going to office hours and "flipped classrooms." On one hand, this helps you build a deeper understanding of the concept being taught. On the other hand, it requires a bigger time commitment. Exams are in between easy and fair - as long as you study and do the reviews, you should be fine. Course is organized; Polak has taught this course many times before.

Lectures were extremely engaging and I really enjoyed listening to Professor Polak's anecdotes. Expectations were clear and well-communicated. PSETs were tough but not unreasonable. Exams about the same. I wish there was a bit more opportunity for review sessions, as peer tutors were helpful but discussion sections were not.

The lectures presented information very efficiently and the problem sets were very deliberately and precisely designed to refresh the lessons of the lecture and facilitate further thinking along the same concepts. There was essentially no wasted time or busywork. Ben Polak is a delight and sprinkles the lectures with just enough wit to keep them lively while explaining the concepts very clearly.

The only weakness is that the Psets didn't have explanations for missing points; you had to go to section to get the full answers.
It is strong in that the lectures are spanning and very good, Polak is a great lecturer. The support around it weren't always excellent and could use work, particularly when it comes to exam prep.
I thought that the format, with in-class games that involved the students, made the course quite engaging despite the large-lecture format.

Strengths: The lectures were engaging and very well organized. The psets were helpful and aligned with the exams in the course. There also were lots of resources to help students with understanding the material. Weaknesses: I wish sections were not just to go over problem set answers. I found that did not help me very much, and I would have preferred to see some other practice problems instead.
My man polak is sensational. Sometimes its hard keeping general lessons and rules straight and applying them to new situations.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it was a great introduction to Game Theory! (with interesting concepts that can apply outside of economics)
Yes
Yes!
Absolutely. No matter what you major in, this course teaches you how to think rationally.

I would highly recommend this course to all students, even people outside of the economics department. Most of the content doesn't require any background knowledge, so it's very accessible for any level of student. On top of that, the content is relatively interesting considering it's all theory and learning game theory can add a really interesting perspective on day to day issues. Professor Polak is also one of the best and most engaging professors I've ever had the pleasure of listening to at Yale.

Highly recommend; it is a fun course that is intellectually stimulating and provides both opportunities for general curious independent studies as well as just the general lecture. There are many avenues for developed learning.
Yes! Regardless of your major or your background, this is an excellent choice.
Absolutely! It is so much fun, has a generous curve, and applies to almost any field that you may work in.
Yes, absolutely - it's far from easy, but tremendously intellectually rewarding, and Prof. Polak's lectures are really excellent. I'm very glad I took it!
Yes, it they need an econ credit

yes! i would recommend it! but do not be fooled by the word game, this class is fun but also really serious and hard imo. prof polak's exam q style is 60% logic + thinking the way he thinks, 40% econ. that being said, it's doable (and maybe even enjoyable) if you do enough of the practice questions and learn his style of reasoning. but definitely not a walk in the park.
Yes, a great Econ elective and Professor Polak made the class fun!

Definitely! One of my favorite classes at Yale, and Professor Polak is such a fun and interesting lecturer. You will not be bored in class. Even if you have to take this class Cr/D/F, it is 1000% worth it.
I would strongly recommend this course to all Yale students; it changes the way you view many aspects of world events and your own life's problems/decisions.

Yes!! This course should be a model for other intro courses. It has a super low barrier to entry (they offered calculus review sessions to anyone who wanted, even thought calculus wasn't even required for exams) and Prof Polak explains everything in a clear, easy-to-understand way. It is also just fun, and worth taking even if you never plan on taking another game theory/econ class.
Yes; take this course to broaden your economic horizons.
Yes--just a cool class
Not unless you need it.
Yes, game theory is very interesting.

Polak is the best professor I've had so far. You get what you put in for this class. Engage in the games that he presents and start the problem sets early so that you have time to think deeply about the problems. The first one or two problem sets are pretty hard but you get adjusted to them.
Yes; very fun, engaging class and not too difficult as long as you study hard for the midterm and final.
Yes, definitely. It's incredibly interesting and engaging.

Highly recommend even to non-econ majors. Class is very engaging (you'll actually like coming to lecture) and professor is actually funny. Plus the material is probably the most interesting that I have learned at Yale

Great course to learn basic concepts of game theory. Standard workload of 1 problem set per week + midterm and final. Easily manageable through going to lecture and office hours. Highly recommend actually going to in-person lecture! Professor Polak is entertaining and a great guy!
I would, the class is incredibly interesting and applicable to concepts and thoughts used in daily life. Professor Polak is a very funny man and is excellent at teaching the content.
Yes, super interesting to learn about game theory and hear from an engaging professor.
Absolutely. I enjoyed this course greatly. I loved doing the problems and going to lecture. I felt like I was using my brain in a really fun way.
Yes, really enjoyed the challenge of approaching complex social and economic problems and developing systems of approach to those problems.

Absolutely! You'll have a lot of fun in lecture and doing psets (they are fun to think about if you have the right attitude). Definitely the best econ lecture I've had. I thought some things we learned had really clear applications to real life. The course is organized really well, and you can get into a rhythm if you plan well. Start the problem sets over the weekend, and take a serious shot at every question. Don't just use the flipped classroom to skip a question on the psets--that'll just make the exams go worse, and you won't learn as much. Try out different sections and office hours to find a good ones.
the games you learn are so interesting and applicable.. just a lot of information
I would, however I took game theory in high school so nothing before the midterm was new information for me
Absolutely! It's a fun course, and one that you would benefit from in a liberal arts curriculum.
yes i enjoyed it
Yes, absolutely. The reasoning skills and game-theory paradigm you take away are both interesting and broadly applicable. The course overall was fun and enjoyable (and reasonably easy).

I took this class as an easier course in a hard senior fall. I went into it hoping to have a fun and interesting time without much work, and it was exactly that. Lectures were always incredibly engaging. The psets were not too difficult and provided fun puzzles to work through. The class was generally pretty low stress. I had a good time and it provided a nice class to round out my semester.
No - exams were super hard but prof is engaging
Yes if you want a social science credit that is fun and not too hard.
Yes, highly.

Everyone should take this course; it is a masterclass in how to think and solve problems. Be prepared to be challenged on some psets and exams, but this is part of the learning that takes place in the course.
no
Yes, interesting introduction to game theory, and techniques used in analyzing game-like situations with payoffs. Professor was funny and made content approachable
1000% yes. Prof Polak is a wonderful lecturer and the concepts covered will surely crop up in everyone's daily life applications.

Yes, I would, especially for Econ majors. I found this course very useful, and especially enjoyed taking it concurrently with intermediate microI thought taking game theory helped me understand some of the later lectures in intermediate micro and complemented the class very well.
Yes, excellent course.

Take as an econ elective. Ben is amazing, the psets arent terrible, the lectures are pretty interesting and engaging and the exams are very fair. Pretty typical Yale econ class, prolly on the more interesting and easy side.
Yes !
I honestly wouldn't recommend. I don't think the exams were a good test of our knowledge, and I felt like I didn't consolidate what I was learning until studying for exams.
Absolutely. This was my favorite course I have ever taken.

Yes! Game theory is such a unique subject and it was really interesting learning about all the different games and strategies over the course of the semester. I will say that game theory as a subject is not as intuitive as I thought it would be and you definitely have to practice a bit to understand concepts in the class. Admittedly I skipped a lot of lectures after the midterm and was cramming hard before the final but the content itself was very fun to learn and it was really satisfying once I "got" topics. Ben Polak was a fantastic lecturer and he really explained concepts well and was able to make the class really interactive. The midterm and final were both pretty fair and workable to get through.
Absolutely, you learn so much and also just an entirely new way of thinking. One of my favorite classes this semester and potentially one of my favorite classes that I have ever taken.
Yes. This class was applicable and very interesting. Polak is a great lectures and the content uses games, examples, and math to prove it all. Very good class.
Only if it is a required course.
Absolutely! I am not an econ major but found this course quite enjoyable. Great for someone with a STEM-y brain but a knack for social sciences/humanities/logic.
Yes! Great type of thinking you won't encounter in another class.

Absolutely- must take regardless of your major. You learn extremely salient topics with wide applicability and the lectures are just fantastic. Polak is amazing, hands down one of the best professors I've had at Yale.

Yes, the lecture is extremely engaging and interesting. I think Game Theory is one the best examples of Economics as a social science that requires critical thinking and theorizing. There are plenty of Teaching Fellows to help you understand the content. I really enjoyed this class a lot.
Definitely, best teacher ever, fun classes with games and examples. Not too difficult. Best class I've taken at Yale

I would recommend this course to another student - but I think that it has a false reputation as 'gutty,' when, in actuality, it requires a good amount of effort to get an A- or an A. Professor Polak is wonderful and witty, though, and teaches incredibly clearly, so I would still highly recommend the class - jsut know that it won't be a true 'gut.'
Yes, one of the most applicable subject matters to other disciplines
Yes I would! It was very well organized and the content was engaging and interesting.

Not really. If you enjoy abstract critical thinking, problem solving, equations, etc then sure, it could be a good class... but if you've never taken an econ class before or you don't like working with numbers, then no. It was a lot more quantitative than I expected
No.
Yes definitely, it enhances the way you approach problems which is a very essential and transferrable skill.
Yes. It is a great introduction to game theory that exposes students to a wide variety of topics. I especially enjoyed the second half of the course (sequential games).
Yes
Very good and I would definitely recommend.

Yes. I think this is a must-take at Yale. ECON 159 teaches you how to think about problems in a way unlike any other course I've taken at Yale. It's also worth taking Game Theory for Professor Polak - he's a very interactive professor and it's fun to be in class. The content can be quite tough sometimes but there's a lot of support from TFs during office hours, which is great.

I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to dig deep into game theory. It is quite theoretical and math-heavy, so you definitely need to be interested in the theoretical concepts, not only the applications. If you do not like theory and math, this course is not for you. However, for anyone looking to better understand this aspect of economics, this course is a fantastic way to do so.
Yes, I would recommend this class for students interested in understanding decision-making and strategy.

YES YES YES 100% For anyone even remotely interested in game theory, totally take it. I would say however be careful to make sure (if you are taking this class for credit) that you have the time to achieve whatever grade you aim for. I would not call this an easy A at all but certainly an easy credit if you want it to be. Take it for Ben, take it for the content, take it for your friends, take it if you're curious!

Yes! I would definitely recommend Game Theory to another student, especially if they enjoy thinking through strategic situations. Professor Polak is a fantastic lecturer and the course introduces you to a number of famous problems/games that are useful to formally solve.

I'd recommend this course to someone interested in the principles of game theory or someone who wants to look at various scenarios in the world from a different, logical lens. It makes for a good elective choice if you have that option
For an Econ credit or a basic understanding of game theory, yes.

Yes, definitely. The framework that it provides and teaches students to look through is really helpful and definitely debunked some of my preconceived notions of what I thought were obvious but actually not realistic. However, if you are not a very logical oriented person or often like to ask questions, you may struggle catching up with the ways to do and think about the problems if you are just going to lectures. Overall, just as content itself, I think this is a great class and certainly a must-take with Professor Polak.

Absolutely. This is an excellent class. I'm not an econ major and just took it for fun and the content is great, and Professor Polak is one of the best lecturers at Yale in my opinion. You have to pay attention in class to stay on top of the content but if you can do that you will love it.
Yes, one of the most fun classes I took this semester

I would definitely recommend this course. I was planning on taking another class but found the first two classes so interesting that I pursued this course instead. While I struggled with the material, it was still a wonderful class to take even if you have to Credit D it.

I would highly recommend this course to any student interested in economics and just thinking about problems in general. I would definitely not say the course was an easy course, but I feel like the workload was very reasonable and TAs were very approachable.
Yes I would recommend this course and really enjoyed the content. While it is challenging in the beginning, things get better as the semester progresses.
Yes! It's an interesting course and the work is not too much. Ben Polak is also a great lecturer and uses fun and engaging examples.
I would recommend the course if a student is interested in Game Theory or it is a credit requirement. Beyond this, the course is at times challenging to follow.
I would recommend this only if you have to take it or if you truly enjoy Econ, otherwise don't.
It's a challenge at times, but definitely worth it if you enjoy problem solving.
Definitely. One of the most intellectually stimulating classes I've taken.
Yes. It is so interesting and applicable to the real world. It is the only Econ class I've taken that I personally felt taught me real things that I'd use going forward.
Yes - take this course even if you're not an econ major. It's not math-intensive and helps you build up core skills that will certainly be useful in other areas.

Yes! If you need a fun QR or econ elective, this is the class to take. Professor Polak is a gem at Yale and is among the most engaging lecturers I have ever had the pleasure of listening to. I will genuinely miss this class. Fun, useful, interesting, and engaging all around. Challenging, yes, but very worth it.
Yes, it is a good introduction to game theory which is important for applications beyond just economics. The class is very interesting as well. Just be prepared for a large workload.

Even if your major does not have any obvious applications of game theory, I would highly recommend the class because it will give you a much better understanding of actions and their consequences in the political and economic worlds. The workload is manageable, and I actually enjoyed doing the psets, as all of the questions seemed meaningful.
Yes, it is a great way to introduce a totally new way of thinking to yourself.
I would recommend it for those who are interested in economics or in the concepts of game theory.

This course was a good introduction to game theory and was a relatively good class to take. The workload was very manageable, and the lectures were engaging. That said, if I could go back in time, I probably would not have taken this course since I am not sure I gained much other than a bunch of definitions of game theory concepts. But, if you like game theory or just want to learn more about it, this is a good course to take.
Yes!
